content.text: Shen Muchuan first noticed that string of characters while scrolling on her phone.
AptS:1548.

While browsing a tiny design forum, she happened to see a thread discussing a project's visual style. The palette was yellow, pink, and blue: clean, crisp, and instantly recognizable. Popular posts usually never reached corners like that, and recommendation algorithms certainly did not push them to her.
She clicked in for a quick look. Then she saw the designation.

AptS:1548. Four letters, one colon, four digits. It looked like a serial number, and also like a codename. She did not know what it meant, but she thought it looked good. Not "interesting," not "I want to understand it". Just simply: good-looking.
The typography of the designation itself, the spacing around the colon, the rhythm between letters and numbers. As a design student, she had an instinctive sensitivity to this kind of thing.
She took a screenshot and saved it to her inspiration folder.
Then she started looking it up.
Not in any serious way, either. Just quick searches while scrolling before bed, or opening a tab for a glance during boring classes. AptS was a designation system. And 1548 was a... android?!
Shen Muchuan stared at the information on the screen for a while.
An android. Okay.
She was not shocked. She was not scared. Her first reaction was: this project's visual system is already good, but it could be better.
That was probably just how a designer's brain worked.
She found 1548's online contact. After two days of hesitation, she sent a message.
Hi. I saw your project's color system and wanted to chat.
Three days later, a reply came.
Chat about what?
Two words. No greeting, no pleasantries.
Shen Muchuan looked at those two words and thought: nice. No small talk needed.
The three-color system is good. But it lacks layering.
You work in design?
Mm.
And that was how the conversation began. Two people with few words, exchanging information in the shortest possible sentences.
